top_rare_diseases.description: A rare genetic disorder characterized by kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities.
top_rare_diseases.overview: Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the type IV collagen found in the body's basement membranes, crucial for kidney, inner ear, and eye function.
top_rare_diseases.clinical_significance: Alport syndrome can lead to end-stage kidney disease and requires monitoring of kidney function, blood pressure, and hearing.
top_rare_diseases.causes: Mutations in the COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 genes.
top_rare_diseases.diagnosis: Genetic testing, kidney biopsy, hearing tests, and eye examinations.
top_rare_diseases.treatment: Management of symptoms, dialysis or kidney transplant for end-stage kidney disease, and hearing aids for hearing loss.
key_aspects: Risk of progression to kidney failure

top_rare_diseases.description: A rare kidney disease characterized by scarring of the glomeruli.
top_rare_diseases.overview: FSGS can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary due to another disease or condition. It leads to nephrotic syndrome.
top_rare_diseases.clinical_significance: FSGS can lead to kidney failure and requires aggressive management.
top_rare_diseases.causes: Primary (unknown cause), genetic mutations, or secondary to another condition.
top_rare_diseases.diagnosis: Kidney biopsy, blood tests, and urine tests.
top_rare_diseases.treatment: Corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and supportive care; dialysis or kidney transplant for advanced disease.
key_aspects: Risk of progression to kidney failure
Variability in presentation and response to treatment

top_rare_diseases.description: A kidney disease characterized by deposits of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli.
top_rare_diseases.overview: IgA nephropathy can cause hematuria and proteinuria, progressing to kidney failure in some cases.
top_rare_diseases.clinical_significance: IgA nephropathy is a leading cause of kidney disease worldwide.
top_rare_diseases.causes: Deposits of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli, often following a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.
top_rare_diseases.diagnosis: Kidney biopsy, blood tests, and urine tests.
top_rare_diseases.treatment: Management of blood pressure and proteinuria; immunosuppressive therapy in some cases; dialysis or kidney transplant for advanced disease.
key_aspects: Risk of progression to kidney failure

top_rare_diseases.description: A rare kidney disease characterized by changes in the glomeruli.
top_rare_diseases.overview: MPGN can be caused by infections, autoimmune disorders, or genetic mutations.
top_rare_diseases.clinical_significance: MPGN can lead to kidney failure and requires monitoring and management.
top_rare_diseases.causes: Infections (e.g., hepatitis B and C), autoimmune disorders, or genetic mutations.
top_rare_diseases.diagnosis: Kidney biopsy, blood tests, and urine tests.
top_rare_diseases.treatment: Management of underlying cause, supportive care, and immunosuppressive therapy; dialysis or kidney transplant for advanced disease.
key_aspects: Risk of progression to kidney failure

top_rare_diseases.description: A rare kidney disease characterized by abnormal activation of the complement system.
top_rare_diseases.overview: C3 glomerulopathy includes dense deposit disease and C3 glomerulonephritis.
top_rare_diseases.clinical_significance: C3 glomerulopathy can lead to kidney failure.
top_rare_diseases.causes: Abnormal activation of the complement system, often due to genetic mutations.
top_rare_diseases.diagnosis: Kidney biopsy, blood tests, and genetic testing.
top_rare_diseases.treatment: Supportive care, immunosuppressive therapy, and complement inhibitors; dialysis or kidney transplant for advanced disease.
key_aspects: Risk of progression to kidney failure
